symptoms.description: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract that commonly causes a runny nose, sneezing, and congestion. Usually lasts 7-10 days and is self-limiting.
medicines: Antihistamines (Loratadine 10mg once daily, Cetirizine 10mg once daily)
Pain relievers (Acetaminophen 500mg every 6 hours, Ibuprofen 400mg every 8 hours)
Zinc lozenges (within 24 hours of symptom onset)
home_remedies: Rest and get adequate sleep (8-10 hours)
Drink plenty of fluids (water, warm tea, soup)
Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air
advices: Stay hydrated by drinking at least 8-10 glasses of water daily
Get plenty of rest to help your immune system fight the infection
Avoid close contact with others to prevent spreading the virus
Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing
Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke
Use disposable tissues and discard them immediately
when_to_see_doctor: Symptoms persist for more than 10 days
High fever (above 101.3°F/38.5°C) that lasts more than 3 days
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
prevention: Boost immune system with proper nutrition
Get adequate sleep and manage stress

symptoms.description: The most common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching sensation and tightness around the forehead, temples, or back of the head and neck. Often triggered by stress, poor posture, or muscle tension.
home_remedies: Apply a cold or warm compress to your head or neck
Take a warm bath or shower
Massage your temples, neck, and shoulders
Rest in a quiet, dark room
advices: Maintain good posture, especially when working at a desk
Take regular breaks from computer screens (20-20-20 rule)
Stay hydrated throughout the day
Manage stress through exercise, yoga, or meditation
Maintain a regular sleep schedule (7-9 hours per night)
Avoid skipping meals
Limit caffeine and alcohol intake
Consider ergonomic adjustments to your workspace
when_to_see_doctor: Headache with fever, stiff neck, confusion, or vision changes
Chronic headache that worsens over time
prevention: Regular exercise (at least 30 minutes, 3-4 times per week)
Avoid triggers (certain foods, strong odors, bright lights)

symptoms.description: An elevated body temperature above 100.4°F (38°C), often a sign that the body is fighting an infection. Can be accompanied by chills, sweating, headache, and muscle aches.
home_remedies: Drink plenty of fluids (water, herbal tea, clear broth)
Rest in a cool, comfortable room
Use a cool, damp washcloth on forehead
advices: Monitor temperature regularly (every 4 hours)
Stay well-hydrated - drink fluids even if not thirsty
Rest and avoid strenuous activities
Don't bundle up with extra blankets if feeling hot
Avoid alcohol and caffeine
Take medications as directed, don't exceed recommended doses
Keep track of other symptoms that develop
when_to_see_doctor: Severe headache, stiff neck, or confusion
Infants under 3 months with any fever
prevention: Avoid close contact with sick individuals
Strengthen immune system with healthy diet

symptoms.description: A reflex action that clears the throat and airways of mucus, irritants, or foreign particles. Can be dry (non-productive) or wet (productive with mucus).
medicines: Dextromethorphan (Robitussin DM 10-20mg every 4 hours) - for dry cough
Guaifenesin (Mucinex 200-400mg every 4 hours) - expectorant for wet cough
Benzonatate (Tessalon Perles 100-200mg three times daily) - prescription
home_remedies: Honey (1-2 tablespoons) with warm water or tea
advices: Identify and avoid irritants (smoke, dust, strong odors)
Stay hydrated - drink at least 8 glasses of water daily
Use a humidifier to keep air moist
Avoid lying flat - prop up with pillows
Don't smoke or expose yourself to secondhand smoke
Avoid very cold or very hot beverages
Cover mouth when coughing to prevent spreading
Try to cough gently to avoid throat irritation
when_to_see_doctor: Coughing up blood or pink-tinged mucus
Green or yellow mucus with foul odor
prevention: Avoid allergens if you have allergies

symptoms.description: Pain, scratchiness or irritation of the throat that often worsens when you swallow. Can be caused by viral infections, bacterial infections, or environmental factors.
medicines: Throat lozenges (Chloraseptic, Cepacol, Halls) - every 2 hours as needed
Pain relievers (Acetaminophen 500mg every 6 hours, Ibuprofen 400mg every 8 hours)
Antibiotics (if bacterial - requires prescription and doctor's diagnosis)
Antihistamines if post-nasal drip is the cause
home_remedies: Warm salt water gargle (1/2 teaspoon salt in 8oz warm water, 3-4 times daily)
Honey and lemon in warm water or tea
Ice chips or popsicles to numb the throat
advices: Rest your voice - avoid shouting or talking loudly
Stay hydrated with warm or cool liquids
Use a humidifier to keep air moist
Avoid irritants like smoke, strong chemicals, or polluted air
Gargle with warm salt water multiple times per day
Eat soft, easy-to-swallow foods
Avoid acidic or spicy foods that may irritate throat
Don't share utensils, cups, or towels
Get adequate rest to support immune function
when_to_see_doctor: Severe throat pain lasting more than 3 days
White patches or pus on tonsils
Hoarse voice lasting more than 2 weeks
prevention: Avoid close contact with people who have throat infections

symptoms.description: Discomfort or pain in the abdominal area, which can be caused by indigestion, gas, overeating, food intolerance, or gastrointestinal conditions.
medicines: Antacids (Tums, Rolaids, Maalox) - as directed on package
Simethicone (Gas-X 125-250mg after meals) for gas and bloating
Loperamide (Imodium 2mg after each loose stool) for diarrhea
home_remedies: Apple cider vinegar in water (1 tbsp in 8oz)
Baking soda in water (1/2 tsp in 4oz)
advices: Eat slowly and chew food thoroughly
Avoid lying down immediately after eating (wait 2-3 hours)
Identify and avoid trigger foods (spicy, fatty, acidic foods)
Stay hydrated with clear fluids
Avoid carbonated beverages and caffeine
Don't eat large meals close to bedtime
Manage stress through relaxation techniques
Avoid tight-fitting clothing around the waist
Keep a food diary to identify problem foods
Eat bland, easily digestible foods during episodes
when_to_see_doctor: Inability to have bowel movement with vomiting
Abdominal swelling or bloating that doesn't improve
prevention: Eat regular meals at consistent times

symptoms.description: An immune system reaction to allergens such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander, causing symptoms like sneezing, itchy/watery eyes, and nasal congestion.
medicines: Antihistamines - Loratadine (Claritin 10mg once daily), Cetirizine (Zyrtec 10mg once daily), Fexofenadine (Allegra 180mg once daily)
Nasal corticosteroid sprays - Fluticasone (Flonase), Triamcinolone (Nasacort), Budesonide (Rhinocort) - 1-2 sprays per nostril daily
home_remedies: Saline nasal rinse or neti pot (twice daily)
Keep windows closed during high pollen days
advices: Monitor pollen counts and stay indoors when counts are high
Keep windows closed during allergy season
Use air conditioning with HEPA filters
Shower and change clothes after being outdoors
Wash bedding weekly in hot water
Use allergen-proof mattress and pillow covers
Remove shoes at the door to avoid tracking pollen inside
Vacuum regularly with HEPA filter vacuum
Avoid hanging laundry outside to dry
Wear sunglasses outdoors to protect eyes
Start medications before allergy season begins
when_to_see_doctor: Symptoms interfere with daily activities or sleep
Severe nasal congestion or facial pain
prevention: Start preventive medications before season begins
Keep indoor environment clean and allergen-free
Consider immunotherapy (allergy shots) for severe cases
Strengthen immune system with healthy lifestyle

symptoms.description: Pain and soreness in the muscles, commonly caused by overuse, tension, minor injuries, stress, or viral infections. Can affect one muscle or multiple muscle groups.
medicines: Topical pain relievers - Bengay, Icy Hot, Biofreeze, Voltaren Gel
home_remedies: Warm bath with Epsom salts (2 cups in warm water)
Heating pad or warm compress (after 48 hours)
Ice pack for acute pain (first 48 hours)
Essential oils (peppermint, lavender) with carrier oil
advices: Rest the affected muscles but avoid complete immobilization
Apply ice for first 24-72 hours, then switch to heat
Stay well-hydrated - drink water before, during, and after activity
Gradually increase intensity of physical activities
Always warm up before exercise and cool down after
Stretch regularly to improve flexibility
Maintain good posture throughout the day
Get adequate sleep for muscle recovery (7-9 hours)
Consider protein intake for muscle repair
Avoid activities that worsen the pain initially
when_to_see_doctor: Severe muscle pain without clear cause
Muscle pain persisting beyond 3 days with home treatment
Muscle weakness or inability to move a body part
Tick bite before muscle pain started
prevention: Use proper form and technique during exercise

symptoms.description: Difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or getting quality sleep, leading to daytime fatigue, irritability, and difficulty concentrating.
medicines: Prescription sleep aids (Zolpidem, Eszopiclone) - doctor consultation required
home_remedies: Herbal teas - Chamomile, Valerian root, Passionflower, Lavender
Tart cherry juice (high in natural melatonin)
Lavender aromatherapy or essential oil on pillow
White noise machine or calming sounds
advices: Maintain consistent sleep schedule (same bedtime and wake time daily)
Create a relaxing bedtime routine (30-60 minutes before sleep)
Keep bedroom cool (60-67°F/15-19°C), dark, and quiet
Avoid screens (phone, TV, computer) 1-2 hours before bed
Limit caffeine after 2 PM
Avoid large meals, alcohol, and nicotine close to bedtime
Exercise regularly but not within 3 hours of bedtime
Use bedroom only for sleep and intimacy
If can't sleep after 20 minutes, get up and do relaxing activity
Avoid clock-watching - turn clock away from view
Limit daytime naps to 20-30 minutes before 3 PM
Get exposure to natural sunlight during the day
when_to_see_doctor: Excessive daytime sleepiness affecting daily activities
Loud snoring or gasping during sleep (possible sleep apnea)
Unusual movements or behaviors during sleep

symptoms.description: A burning sensation in the chest or throat caused by stomach acid flowing back into the esophagus. Can worsen when lying down or after eating.
medicines: Antacids - Tums, Rolaids, Maalox (as needed, after meals)
H2 blockers - Famotidine (Pepcid 10-20mg twice daily), Cimetidine (Tagamet)
Proton pump inhibitors - Omeprazole (Prilosec 20mg once daily), Lansoprazole (Prevacid 15-30mg), Esomeprazole (Nexium 20mg)
home_remedies: Apple cider vinegar (diluted, 1 tbsp in water before meals)
Baking soda in water (1/2 tsp in 4oz water)
Chew sugar-free gum after meals (increases saliva)
Aloe vera juice (1/2 cup before meals)
advices: Elevate head of bed 6-8 inches (use bed risers, not just pillows)
Avoid lying down for 2-3 hours after eating
Eat smaller, more frequent meals instead of large meals
Avoid trigger foods: spicy, fatty, fried foods, chocolate, caffeine, alcohol, citrus, tomatoes, onions, mint
Lose weight if overweight (reduces abdominal pressure)
Wear loose-fitting clothing around waist and stomach
Don't eat within 3 hours of bedtime
Sleep on left side (reduces reflux)
Quit smoking (weakens lower esophageal sphincter)
Manage stress through relaxation techniques
Stay upright during and after meals
Avoid bending over or straining after eating
when_to_see_doctor: Heartburn occurring more than twice a week
Symptoms persist despite lifestyle changes and OTC medications
Difficulty swallowing or pain when swallowing
Weight loss due to poor appetite or difficulty eating
Black, tarry stools or vomiting blood
Chronic cough, hoarseness, or asthma-like symptoms
Chest pain (rule out heart problems first - call 911 if severe)

symptoms.description: Feelings of worry, nervousness, or unease about an event or situation. Can manifest with physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat, sweating, and difficulty concentrating.
medicines: Herbal supplements - Ashwagandha (300-500mg twice daily), Valerian root, Passionflower
Prescription medications (SSRIs, benzodiazepines) - requires doctor consultation
advices: Practice deep breathing exercises daily (5-10 minutes)
Exercise regularly - at least 30 minutes, 5 days per week
Maintain regular sleep schedule (7-9 hours per night)
Limit caffeine and avoid energy drinks
Avoid alcohol and nicotine
Eat balanced, nutritious meals at regular times
Stay connected with supportive friends and family
Set realistic goals and prioritize tasks
Take breaks and schedule relaxation time
Practice mindfulness or meditation (10-20 minutes daily)
Challenge negative thoughts with positive reframing
Limit news and social media exposure if it increases anxiety
Create a calming environment at home
Use time management techniques to reduce overwhelm
when_to_see_doctor: Anxiety interfering with daily activities, work, or relationships
Avoiding normal activities due to anxiety
Anxiety persisting for 6 months or more
Substance use to cope with anxiety
